subject: Re: New to the Quikscript
msgSnippet: ... English ... conventions, ... manual ... (I ... reading, ... discovered ... fascinated ... common er ... discovered ... fascinated ... common er ... wow
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Robert McBroom <info@o...>
wrote:
> Welcome to the group!
>
> I have been playing with QS for almost a year, and I have just come
> to the conclusion, after much wrestling with Read's manual, and
> arguing with his ideas, that he was right in his approach all along.
>
> Read evolved QS from Shavian (which he also invented) after a
> lengthy correspondence with English speakers all over the gobe, and
> quickly realized that it was hopeless to try and create a feasible
> communication tool that took into account all the vagaries of
English
> pronunciation. Therefore, with logic and speed being his utmost
> goals, he established "rules" for QS spelling.
>
> It is now apparent to me that QS is a series of spelling
conventions,
> designed to make handwriting (and reading) faster, more economical,
> and - eventually - easier. It is merely a series of (somewhat)
> arbitrary rules, just as traditional orthography is, except that it
> is more rational, and therefore more easily learned.
>
> Of course, you are free to obey the rules or not, depending on how
> much you will be interacting with other QS writers. Even I can't
> agree with a few.
>
> Those whose interest tend towards establishing a "standard of
> pronunciation" however, are more prone to the Yahoo Shavian group,
> where this debate has been stewing for years.
>
> I have tried to digest most of his conventions from Read's QS
manual
> and arranged them in (perhaps) a more convenient way than he did.
(I
> see they were not detailed on the Omniglot site.) The results are
> below.
>
> ***************************
>
> The spelling is in Senior QS, using half-letters where called for.
>
> I suggest transfering the text to a spreadsheet, to easily reformat
> the letters in the "QS" column to the Jerome font for proper
reading,
>
> The "!" indicates the syllable is stressed.
>
> Roman QS Sample word
>
> al- ul- allot
> al-! Al- allocate
> an- an- annul
> an-! An- annual
> ar- x- arrive
> ar!- Ar- arrow
> be- bi- begin
> com- km- compose
> com-! kom- compost
> con- kG- conform
> con-! koG- contact
> de- di- decide
> de-! de- definite
> en- iG- enlarge
> in- iG- inquire
> ob- ab- obtain
> ob-! ob obstacle
> of- af- offend
> of-! of- offer
> per- px- persuade
> pre- ]ri- prevent
> pre-! ]re present (n.)
> pro- ]ra- protect
> pro-! ]rO- protest
> pur- px- pursue
> re- ri- refuse
> re-! re- rebel (n.)
> un- an- unless
> unn- ann- unknown
> -able -abl livable
> -ably -abli reasonably
> -age -aJ cabbage
> -ain -an certain
> -ain! -EG obtain
> -al -l tribal
> -ally -ali finally
> -ance -ans distance
> -ant -ant distant
> -ar -x pillar
> -asion -EJG occasion
> -ation -ESG action
> -cean -SG ocean
> -ched -ct poached
> -ches -cL switches
> -cious -Sus precious
> -ded -dB ended
> -e -i simile
> -ea -W area
> -ea! -Ia idea
> -ean -Wn Korean
> -ean! -Ian Korean
> -ear! -Ix appear
> -ee! -I payee
> -ee -i coffee
> -eer! -Ix career
> -el -l level
> -en -an happen
> -ence -ans presence
> -ent -ant present (n.)
> -er -x maker
> -ers -xz makers
> -ess -es hostess
> -est -est highest
> -ey -i money
> -ful -ful careful
> -fully -fuli carefully
> -ges -JL bridges
> -ghed -ft roughed
> -gion -JG region
> -ia -W India
> -iage -iJ carriage
> -ial -il burial
> -ian -Wn Indian
> -ible -abl flexible
> -ibly -abli flexibly
> -ie -i lassie
> -ier -ix happier
> -ier! -Ix pier
> -il -l devil
> -ily -ili merrily
> -inging -iNN bringing
> -ion -jan million
> -ior -ix senior
> -ir -x fakir
> -ity -i[i sanctity
> -ked -kt licked
> -land -lnd England
> -le -l eagle
> -less -les hopeless
> -ling -lN calling
> -man -mn seaman
> -men -meG seamen
> -ment -mn[ payment
> -ness -nes goodness
> -on -an ribbon
> -or -x author
> -ous -us various
> -ped -pt topped
> -re -x mitre
> -scious -Sus conscious
> -ses -zL pleases
> -ses -sz kisses
> -shed -St washed
> -shes -SL dishes
> -shion -SG fashion
> -sion -ZG vision
> -ssed -st missed
> -ssion -SG mission
> -ted -tB fitted
> -thed -Tt frothed
> -ting -tN writing
> -tion -SG action
> -tious -Sus pretentious
> -us -us circus
> -ving -vN living
> -ward -wd forward
> -wards -wdL onwards
> -y -i happy
> -ying -iN carrying
> -yr -x martyr
>
>
>
>
> > Hello everyone. :) I'm a new to the board; I just
discovered
> >the Read Alphabet the other day on Omniglot.com and I was
fascinated
> >by the idea of using a different script to write English. I've got
> >most of the letters down (at least in its "junior" form), but there
> >are some letters that I'm not sure how to use, and some sounds for
> >which I'm not sure which letter to use, for instance the
common "er"
> >suffix, as in "maker".
> > Also, I was wondering how users of the alphabet deal with
> >different pronounciations due to differences in dialect. Is there
> >a "standard" Read form for each English word, or would one simply
> >write the words as his or her dialect pronounces them?
> > If these questions have been answered anywhere else on board,
> >could someone direct me to the thread they're in? Thanks.
> >
> >Ryan
> >
>
>
> > Hello everyone. :) I'm a new to the board; I just
discovered
> >the Read Alphabet the other day on Omniglot.com and I was
fascinated
> >by the idea of using a different script to write English. I've got
> >most of the letters down (at least in its "junior" form), but there
> >are some letters that I'm not sure how to use, and some sounds for
> >which I'm not sure which letter to use, for instance the
common "er"
> >suffix, as in "maker".
> > Also, I was wondering how users of the alphabet deal with
> >different pronounciations due to differences in dialect. Is there
> >a "standard" Read form for each English word, or would one simply
> >write the words as his or her dialect pronounces them?
> > If these questions have been answered anywhere else on board,
> >could someone direct me to the thread they're in? Thanks.
> >
> >Ryan
> >
> --
> - Robert McBroom
> Manager
> Onteora Mountain House
> Boiceville NY
> 845-657-6233




wow it seems that omniglot is taking over the scholarly underground
by storm as i too have found quickscript on it. any advice would be
awsome..new to this today. thanks
as always
sam
